title: Handcuffed man set himself on fire in back of police van
text:
The suspect was searched three times but officers failed to spot the lighter in one of his pockets (Picture: Getty Images)

A man who was arrested, handcuffed and put in the back of a police van managed to set himself on fire en route to the station after officers missed the lighter in his pocket, a review found.

Police Scotland responded to reports of a knifeman involved in a disturbance in Arbroath and apprehended the 42-year-old at the scene.

According to an investigation by the Police Investigations & Review Commissioner (PIRC) the suspect was searched three times before entering the van.

But the arresting officers missed the lighter he had concealed inside a knee-height pocket.

During the journey to Dundee Custody Centre a special constable spotted the man taking it out but declined to mention it or confiscate the lighter before the suspect ignited his clothes.

During the journey to the station a special constable spotted the lighter but failed to mention it (Picture: Getty Images)

He suffered ‘serious injuries’ requiring treatment after burning his right arm during the incident in February and was subsequently convicted following his discharge from hospital.

The PIRC’s investigation into how the arrested man was able to set himself on fire has now submitted a number of recommendations for Police Scotland, including advice to sit facing prisoners while they are in the back of police vans.

Despite the van used to transport the suspect having a rear-facing seat which would have allowed an officer to sit facing him, the report found that ‘the officer responsible for monitoring the man sat in one of the front forward seats’.

Police Scotland have since confirmed to the PIRC that guidance about how to conduct ‘professional, effective and diligent searches’ has been given to officers to try to reduce the chances of a similar incident happening again.

Further advice has also been issued on the risks of cuffing a person’s hands in front of their body when in custody.

Superintendent Norrie Conway said: ‘Our officers and staff work with commitment and professionalism day in, day out, to provide a high quality policing service for the public, including those in our care.

‘They work in challenging situations in real time and when learning opportunities are identified, Police Scotland is committed to supporting officers and staff where they act in good faith.

‘We have already reiterated the importance of effective searches and clarified guidance on seating arrangements in vehicles. We will reflect on the PIRC’s findings to see if we can do more to improve how we serve the public.’

description: A review revealed the man was searched three times before getting in but officers missed the lighter he'd hidden in a knee-height pocket.
